Name: Musk xylene
Description: Musk xylene is a C-nitro compound that is m-xylene bearing three nitro substituents at positions 2, 4 and 6 as well as a tert-butyl group at position 5. It has a role as an explosive, a fragrance and a carcinogenic agent. It is functionally related to a 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene and a m-xylene.

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Rimkus GG, Wolf M; Chemosphere 30: 641-51 (1995) (2) Kallenborn R et al; Fresenius Environ Bull 10: 832-842 (2001) (3) Duedahl-Olesen, L et al; Chemosphere 61: 422-431 (2005) (4) Li Z et al; Wat Res 45: 1403-13 (2011)(5) O'Tolle S, Metcalfe C; J Great Lake Res 32: 361-369 (2006) (6) Schmid P et al; Chemosphere 67: S16-S21 (2007)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Musk xylene was detected in a variety of fish collected from German fish-markets (1990-1992), German fish-farms (Spring 1990 and Winter 1992/1993), and German rivers (Summers 1991-1993) as well as mussels and shrimp from the German North Sea Coast (1991-1994) at concentrations ranging from <0.01 to 1.06 mg/kg fat, 0.01 to 0.04 mg/kg fat, and 0.01 mg/kg fat for fish, mussels, and shrimp respectively(1). Musk xylene was detected in 18 of 25 Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua), haddock (Melanogrammus), thornback ray (Raia clavata), and saithe (Pollachius virens) fish livers and fillets from harbors in Norway in Winter 1997/98 at concentrations ranging from <0.1 ng/g lipids to 178 ng/g, average 28.9 ng/g lipids(2). Musk xylene was detected in trout collected from different fish farms in the western part of Denmark between September 1999 to January 2000 and again between September 2003 to January 2004 at concentrations ranging from <0.18 to 1.59 ug/kg fresh weight, median 0.52 ug/kg fresh weight and <0.23 and 1.30 ug/kg fresh weight, median <0.23 ug/kg fresh weight, respectively(3). Musk xylene was detected in wild brown trout muscle tissue, at concentrations of 48.7-262.2 ug/kg, sampled downstream from sewage treatment plants in Prachatice, Brloh, and Pacov, Czech Republic during June 2009; it was not detected above the limit of quantification upstream of these sites(4). Musk xylene was not detected in bullhead, shad, and perch fish sampled from Hamilton Harbor of Lake Ontario, the Detroit River, and western Lake Erie, in Spring 2002(5). Musk xylene was detected in fish from the alpine lakes in Grisons, Switzerland at concentrations in ng/g lipid based of 1.9, 12, 1.8, 1.9, 1.3, 2.5, and 2.2 in L. Tuma, L. Linghin, L. Moesols, Surettasee, L. Diavolezza, L. Teo, and L. Grond, respectively(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Tas JW et al; Chemosphere 35: 2973-3002 (1997). Available from, as of Jul 12, 2017: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9415982?dopt=Abstract (2) Duedahl-Olesen L et al; Chemosphere 61: 422-431 (2005)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Musk xylene was detected in yellow eels (13 samples)in the Netherlands in lakes and rivers in 1994 at a concentration range of <0.004-0.08 mg/kg wet weight, median 0.03 mg/kg and <0.02-0.43 mg/kg fat, median 0.13 mg/kg fat. In a second sampling program in 1996, the concentrations of musk xylene in yellow  eels (10 samples) ranged from <0.0005-0.045 mg/kg wet weight, median 0.014 mg/kg(1). Musk xylene was detected in trout collected from Danish fish farms at concentrations ranging from below the detection limit to 71.0 ug/kg with a mean concentration of 12.0 ug/kg in 1992; at concentrations ranging from below the detection limit to 1.59 ug/kg with a mean concentration of 0.72 ug/kg in 1999; and at concentrations ranging from below the detection limit to 0.55 ug/kg with a mean concentration of not detected/below the detection limit in 2003(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Musk xylene was detected in core sediment samples collected from Lake Ontario between August 7-12, 2003 with core dating giving approximate dry weight concentrations of 0.08 ng/g in 1895, 0.45 ng/g in 1925, 0.1 ng/g in 1945, 0.85 ng/g in 1960, 0.3 ng/g in 1975 and 0.0 ng/g in 1990(1).

SEDIMENT: Musk xylene was detected in San Francisco Bay sediments at a mean concentration of 0.034 ng/g and in the nearby wastewater treatment plant effluent at concentrations ranging from 0.13-0.24 ng/g(1).
